explanation: Agent A is correct. The memcmp call reads new_nonce_len bytes from both nn->nonce and new_nonce. In the shown function there is no guaranteed runtime check that the object pointed to by new_nonce is at least new_nonce_len bytes long (the code only contains mhd_assert checks which may be compiled out and some checks/asserts about nn->nonce but not a robust check of new_nonce’s buffer length). Therefore the call can result in out-of-bounds accesses and violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 unless an external, enforced contract (or additional runtime checks) guarantees new_nonce’s size. To be compliant the code must ensure at runtime (not only by asserts) that both buffers are at least new_nonce_len bytes long before calling memcmp.
